ui.foyerBreakMsg: Want to head to the foyer for a chat?

act1.left: m₁D₁ was already in motion!
...important! We record the curtain opening as the moment t₀=0!
...this motion is straight-line and back-and-forth!
...and repeating, periodic, so it’s an oscillation!
Could it be Simple Harmonic Motion?
...but if it *is* SHM, then the values we measure should satisfy x=A·sin(ωt+φ₀), right?
...so if we draw an x–t graph, could it confirm it?
Hmm, yes and no. Still, let’s do it, because a graph usually reveals things!
...Anyway, if it’s SHM, it should have amplitude A={A} m!
...and period T={T} s! so in that case it also has ω={omega} rad/s!
If the motion is SHM, then the points on a plot of x ... versus sin(ωt+φ₀) must lie on a straight line with slope A!
Exactly! So if the curve x=A·sin(ωt+φ₀) ... and the graph x–sin(ωt+φ₀) is a straight line, then it’s proven to be SHM!
Sure… but it looks like there’s an unknown initial phase φ₀, which makes that check impossible for now…
But if we find on the x–t graph the time t₁ ... where x=A·sin(ωt), more precisely x=A·sin(ω(t−t₁))
...exactly! and then the problem becomes simple. Look what we can do: t₁={tZero}s where the red arrow points on x–t...
...So we get the red curve that corresponds ... and for x=A·sin(ωt) we can say, from there on! ...
Perfect! 1) We see that the two curves match perfectly, and 2) the graph x–sin(ωt) is indeed a straight line with slope A!
...so the motion is SHM! And since x₀={x0} m, ... φ₀={phi0}°={phi0rad}rad. Haha—one down! Moving on!
...so the velocity is given by the law v=ωA·cos(ωt+φ₀)!
...and the acceleration by the law a=−ω²A·sin(ωt+φ₀)!
But the relation x=A·sin(ωt+φ₀) (1) is contained in (3)...! So the new law can also be written as a(x)=−ω²x
Perfect! The full set of SHM laws!
Hmm… Now we need to see how m₁D₁ pulls off SHM!

Ok, what did we achieve so far—and with what tools? 1. We used exclusively the measurements x and t 2. From the features of periodic motion we formed the hypothesis that the motion is SHM 3. We proved, through a chain of reasoning, that it is SHM 4. We brought out all the laws of this motion!

act2.left: Whoa! m₁D₁ is tied to a spring!
Look! The titles now reveal the mass: m₁={m1}Kg! ... and on the spring there’s the label D₁.
...I’ve seen this exact m₁D₁ before dragging a mass–spring setup in another show, but with a different producer!
...yeah, and even there he moved obsessively with the same period T={T}s, but with a bigger amplitude A=5m!
Anyway—let’s see what exactly he’s doing here, and more importantly: why?
Hmm… I’m getting the vibe that the Protagonist is probably the moving actor *and* his tools together!
Now it makes sense why they don’t call him m₁ but m₁,D₁!…
…m₁ is the actor’s mass but, as an oscillator... there is also the elastic cause–force, which is what that D₁ seems to stand for!
…so m₁ and D₁ go everywhere as a package deal! and the two together are the oscillator—the protagonist!

...meaning every oscillator is characterized
1. by its mass m and
2. by the elastic cause–force, which sets the timing (T) of the oscillation!
...I’m starting to get why its “signature name” is mD and not just m!...

So the uniqueness of each oscillator—its “obsession”, i.e. the characteristic period T (and thus f and ω)—must be due to... 1. the “body type” of the oscillator, i.e. its mass m 2. and the elastic cause (that D in its name)!
Daaamn, guys. That’s a lot of talking. Drop it and let’s move on…!
Alright. So how do we write Newton’s 2nd law for the oscillator case?
…uh, no big deal: ΣF = m·a, but... here, using (3): ΣF = −mω²A·sin(ωt+φ₀) (5)!
...and based on (4) it can also be written as ΣF = −mω²x (6)!
Notice that (6) contains the actor’s two constants—if we may: the “body type” (m) and the “obsession” (ω)!
Should we combine those two constants into one and call it D = mω² (6’)? Does that make sense?

Great idea! 1. Let’s give the symbol D to the elastic cause–force. 2. That way we eliminate a symbol from our formulas. 3. It also gets a “face” because D is written on the spring. 4. And it makes it clear that D belongs to the “tool” that forces the actor to oscillate. 5. In general we’ll call D the oscillator’s “elastic constant”.
...okay, and this also explains why the actor, no matter the spring or the producer, “obsessively” keeps his period constant?
...Exactly! (6’) D = mω² shows it: since m and D are constant, then ω=√(D/m) is also constant for the moving actor!
…so, rightly, they call the protagonist–oscillator (=actor + elastic cause) (m,D)!
And we can, with a simple numerical substitution, compute D₁ for our m₁D₁: D₁=m₁ω²={D1}N/m
…and (6)—don’t forget—becomes ΣF = −D·x (7)!
Which expresses Newton’s 2nd law for SHM: “A body performs SHM if and only if the net force on it is proportional to its displacement and directed opposite to it.”
OK. So far we saw SHM (ideal). To start cleanly, I set f=OFF and b=0.
If the system is truly ideal, the amplitude should stay at A=3 m. (Reality, of course, laughs.)
Now let’s do reality: damping. I set b=6 with f=OFF. That’s damped oscillation.
Key point: amplitude decays, but the system’s “own” frequency doesn’t vanish. Energy just leaks out.
And now… driving. Keep b=6 and set f≠0 with frequency ratio f/f₀=0.60. (Forced oscillations begin.)
You’ll see a transient, then it settles into a steady amplitude. That final amplitude depends strongly on f/f₀.
Let’s hunt it properly: change frequency and build the resonance curve A–(f/f₀).
Step 1: f/f₀=0.75. Let a few cycles pass so the amplitude stabilizes and a point gets recorded.
Step 2: f/f₀=0.90. Getting close…
Step 3: f/f₀=1.00. The main resonance party (as far as damping allows).
Step 4: f/f₀=1.10. Past the peak, amplitude drops again.
Now change b to see what damping does to resonance: larger b makes the peak lower and the curve wider.
I increase damping to b=12 (driving stays on). Watch how the amplitude around 1.00 drops.
Again f/f₀=1.00 with larger b. Resonance is still there, just “trimmed”.
And that’s the whole path: undamped → damped → forced → resonance curves, driven by the dialogue itself.

foyer.left: Relations (1), (2), (3) and (5)
foyer.right: (1) x(t)=A·sin(ωt+φ₀) (2) υ(t)=ωA·cos(ωt+φ₀) (3) α(t)=−ω²A·sin(ωt+φ₀) (5) ΣF(t)=−m·ω²A·sin(ωt+φ₀)

foyer.left: ...help us “predict” position, velocity, acceleration and net force at any moment, without having to go back in for the rest of the show!
Right! Similarly, (3)’ and (6)
...help us “predict” acceleration and net force as functions of position… without us being forced to keep being spectators!

Alright!
1. We see, my dear people, that for now we can’t ... reach a clean conclusion about velocity and its relation to the position of (m₁ ,D₁).
2. But I think what we’ve seen so far in the show ... generalizes to any protagonist (m,D) in a similar SHM show.
...3. As people who know their …Algebra, and with a bit of “algebraic curiosity” we can cover that too (without waiting for Act 3!), to fill Gap 1 mentioned by Viewer 3. ✓ Solve (1) for sin(ωt+φ₀)
foyer.right:
(1) x=A·sin(ωt+φ₀) ⇒ sin(ωt+φ₀)=x/A
...

foyer.left: Right! Do the same for (2): solve for cos(ωt+φ₀)
foyer.right: (2) υ=ωA·cos(ωt+φ₀) ⇒ cos(ωt+φ₀)=υ/(ωA) and square cos²(ωt+φ₀)= υ²/(ω²A²) since sin²(ωt+φ₀)+cos²(ωt+φ₀)=1 add term by term ⇒ 1 = x²/A² + υ²/(ω²A²) (8)

foyer.left: ✓Here’s the relation we were missing! Now we can “predict” velocity at any moment when we know the protagonist’s position on stage, and ✓We can (thinking similarly) derive a relation between acceleration and velocity! That is, here we “play with” (3) and (2).
...of course! of course! Solve (3) for sin(ωt+φ₀) and (2) for cos(ωt+φ₀), square them, and add.
foyer.right: (3) ⇒ sin²(ωt+φ₀)=α²/(ω⁴A²), (2) ⇒ cos²(ωt+φ₀)=υ²/(ω²A²) and add term by term ⇒ 1 = α²/(ω⁴A²) + υ²/(ω²A²) (9) bingo!

foyer.left:
...but isn’t it even better if we solve (8) for υ! meaning:
...
  ⇔     E<sub>mech</sub>       =        U       +        K
  i.e. “P.C.M.E.”?
foyer.right:
(8) 1 = x²/A² + υ²/(ω²A²)
⇔ ω²A² = ω²x² + υ²

foyer.left: …hold up!
Let me finish, please… solving for υ gives
foyer.right: ⇔ υ = ±ω·√(A²−x²) ⁽¹⁰⁾ and that’s the desired relation of oscillator speed vs position!

foyer.left: ...and from (9), similarly solving for α...
foyer.right: (9) 1 = α²/(ω⁴A²) + υ²/(ω²A²) ⇔ α = ±ω·√(ω²A² − υ²) ⁽¹¹⁾ and that’s the desired relation of oscillator acceleration vs speed!

foyer.left: hmm yes—and if we think that ωA = υ_max
which means that now (11) and (11’) help us “predict” acceleration as long as we know the actor’s speed!
...but Viewer 1 wanted to say something!
The point where I stopped had written ω²A² = ω²x² ... If we multiply both sides by ½m, look— the relation becomes:
foyer.right: ½ m ω²A² = ½ m ω²x² + ½ m υ² ⁽¹²⁾

foyer.left: But then the term ½ m υ² is the kinetic energy of the protagonist (m,D).
foyer.right: K = ½ m υ²

foyer.left: ...hmm! And that term is added to ½ m ω² x², which turns out to be the potential energy U (due to position) of the protagonist (m,D)!
foyer.right: U= ½ m ω² x²

foyer.left: ...Therefore, the term ½ m ω² A² on the left – First must, as the sum K+U, represent the mechanical energy EM of the protagonist (m,D).
foyer.right: Emech= ½ m ω² A²

foyer.left: ...So you’re saying that (12) shows the validity of a Principle of Conservation of Mechanical Energy?
foyer.right: ⁽¹²⁾ ½ m ω²A² = ½ m ω²x² + ½ m υ² ⇔ Emech = U + K i.e. “P.C.M.E.”?

foyer.left: Don’t rush! We didn’t conclude yet that this ... (12) leads us to a “P.C.M.E. (oscillator)” for the protagonist oscillator (m,D)!
foyer.right:
E<sub>mech</sub>= ½ m ω² A² = constant ⇔ 
“P.C.M.E. (oscillator)” of protagonist (m,D)

foyer.left: – Second, comparing Emech= ½ m ω² A² with U= ½ m ω² x² (note: at maximum displacement!), we see that ½ m ω² A² is also the maximum potential energy U_max of (m,D).
foyer.right: Emech= ½ m ω² A² = U_max

foyer.left: ...– Third, ½ m ω² A², as mechanical energy, will also equal the maximum kinetic energy of the oscillator—when x=0, i.e. at the equilibrium position.
foyer.right: Emech=½ m ω² A²=Umax=Kmax

foyer.left: So basically, we now even know the show’s … budget! Without having to watch Act 3 about energy! We’ve… seen this before?
Of course we know the budget! We can compute it right here with a simple substitution.
foyer.right: in the relation Emech=½DA² which gives Emech={Emech}J

foyer.left: Right! That “algebraic curiosity”, which so often ... ends up giving the relation D=mω²—the one we also put into (7) ΣF = −D·x ...
foyer.right: D=mω²

foyer.left: ...which is what you’d want to say: if we use it in (12), it becomes:
foyer.right: ½ D A² = ½ D x² + ½ m υ² ⁽¹³⁾ i.e. P.C.M.E. (oscillator) for each (m,D)

foyer.left: Basically, I’m down to leave too—but with an aftertaste from tonight’s show of (m₁,D₁). Let’s summarize:
foyer.right: The protagonist oscillator (m,D) is characteriz... by its “body type” (m) and its “timing obsession” (ω)

foyer.left: ...or equivalently—and let’s keep this:
foyer.right: The protagonist oscillator is fully defined by its own (m,D)!

foyer.left: ...So from now on, for us it will hold:
foyer.right: 1. The oscillator (m,D) sets its own ω, f, T for the SHM it will perform 2. The limits in its show (path length – with ... via the mechanical energy Emech it invests, and 3. the start of SHM and therefore the (φ₀), are always set by us, the viewers!

foyer.left: So… Shall we leave?
Of course!
